newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Victorias creditors eye bail-out plan.
newsitem.headline: Victorias creditors eye bail-out plan.

text.p: Creditors of the Philippines' Victorias Milling Corp on Monday reached a consensus to draw up a "restructuring plan" to aid the cash-strapped firm, an official of a creditor bank said.

Representatives of the 32 creditors at a meeting formed a special committee to negotiate a bail-out plan for the country's largest sugar miller in talks starting on Tuesday. Victorias' oustanding debts total 4.423 billion pesos ($168 million).
"There was a consensus to form a restructuring plan," said the official, who asked not to be named.
An official of another creditor bank said the creditors had agreed to negotiate "as a group."
"We hope to sit down with Victorias and try to look at its financial condition at the moment," said the official.
The creditors, who include banks and investment houses, last week agreed in principle to grant a 90-day moratorium on principal repayments of Victorias's debts.

Land Bank of the Philippines, Philippine Commercial International Bank and the Bank of the Philippine Islands have been appointed to represent "secured creditors" - or creditors who had collaterals on their loans to Victorias - in Tuesday's talks, said the bank officials, requesting anonymity.
Development Bank of the Philippines and the Philippine Savings Bank will represent the so-called "unsecured creditors," or those without collaterals, they said.
Asian Bank Corp will represent the small creditors while Deutsche Bank has been appointed to represent the foreign creditors, they added.

Victorias asked for a 90-day debt moratorium from creditors to improve its cash-flow. The firm blamed the steep drop in sugar prices to 480 pesos three months ago from 800 pesos at the start of 1996 to a glut because of what it said was over-importation from neighbouring countries.
The firm hopes to get a partner to infuse up to two billion pesos for a 35 to 40 percent stake to aid its recovery.
